awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Structures in Topology Conference, San Juan, Puerto Rico
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for the conference “Algebraic structures in topology” in San Juan, Puerto Rico, to be held on May 30th-June 3rd, 2022. The conference will focus on recent developments in algebraic topology and its applications to geometric topology, mathematical physics, and algebraic geometry. This event aims to bring together mathematicians from diverse subfields in algebraic topology, who use similar techniques to achieve different goals and foster new ideas and perspectives. The conference will feature plenary talks, mini-courses, contributed talks, and time for informal interactions. Another major goal of the conference is outreach to mathematicians from unrepresented racial and ethnic groups who may feel isolated from the larger mathematical community. 

The guiding theme of the conference is the use of algebraic and categorical techniques to better understand the homotopy theory of spaces, the algebraic topology of manifolds, and algebro-geometric objects. The following are among the topics that will be highlighted at the conference: the theory of operads, equivariant homotopy theory, higher category theory and derived algebra, Hochschild homology theory of structured algebras, and algebraic K-theory. More information is available at the conference website https://sites.google.com/view/algebraicstructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The grant allowed the PI and co-PI to hold the conference "Algebraic Structures in Topology Conference, San Juan, Puerto Rico" from May 30th to June 3rd, 2022. This conference featured lecture series by Mona Merling and Boris Tsygan, invited research talks by Anna Marie Bohmann, Ralph Kaufmann, Inbar Klang, Hana Kong, Alexander Kupers, Nick Rozenblyum, Bernardo Uribe, Inna Zakharevich, and Mahmoud Zeinalian, as well as contributed talks by Thomas Brazelton, Jeffrey Carlson, Renee Hoekzema, Peter Patzt, Maximilien Peroux, Pennsylvania, Kate Poirier, Piotr Pstragowski, Carmen Rovi, Julia Semikina, Yuri Sulyma, and Miguel Xicotencatl. This conference was attended by approximately a total of 50 participants. 

Intellectual merit

The conference brought together researchers working in homotopy theory and its applications to geometry, topology, algebra, mathematical physics, and even to fields that are farther away such as probability. Speakers presented recent advances on a wide range of topics including algebraic K-theory, diffeomorphism groups, rational and stable homotopy theory, higher category theory, topological quantum field theories, string topology, and Hochschild homology. The conference was broad and encompassing in terms of topics but the talks were tied through the common thread of using algebraic structures (seen from the lens of homotopy theory) in different kinds of geometric settings. This resulted in the crosspollination of ideas between different research groups that use similar techniques but do not interact often. For example, there were fruitful interactions between researches studying chain-level (differential graded) algebraic structures on Hochschild homology and those who work with spectra and topological versions of this theory.  Additionally, researchers studying Steinberg modules from the perspective of homological stability engaged with those studying Steinberg modules with applications to cut-and-paste K-theory.   

Broader impact

The structure of the conference was designed to promote training of early career stage mathematicians of different backgrounds. We instructed the mini-course speakers to make their talks accessible to graduate students. The contributed talks were valuable for graduate students and postdocs and it gave them the opportunity to practice giving talks as well as exposure. We included sufficient downtime for researchers of different levels (junior and senior faculty, postdocs, and graduate students) to interact and exchange ideas. New research projects and collaborations were started as a consequence. 

Diversity and inclusion were key to the mission of the conference. Half of the invited speakers were women. The conference also featured a strong pressence of Hispanic, Latinx, and Latin American participants. In fact, the conference was held in a Spanish speaking region (Puerto Rico) precisely for it to be welcoming to Hispanic participants. We also engaged with the local mathematical community. The geographic location of the connference was also strategically chosen in order to create a bridge between the mathematical communities in the United States, Europe, and those in Latin America. We had participans from all of these communities. The general atmosphere of the conference was relaxed, respectful, and, as a consquence, conducive to fruitful mathematical and professional interactions.
